As it is said:

That is to say, when compiling the canon, the assembly of bodhisattvas all said together:

The bodhisattva who transmits the Dharma then gave his permission, saying:

This matter is like this, up to here it should be spoken, definitely no different.
For these four meanings, at the beginning of the sÅ«tras, all say 'Thus have I heard'.
The Tripiá¹­aka Master ParamÄrtha says:
The subtle vinaya clarifies that when Ä€nanda ascended the seat to compile the Dharma canon, his body was like that of the Buddhas, endowed with all the major and minor marks.
When he descended from the seat, he returned to his original form.
Examining the collected biographies, it is also said like this.
The assembly had three doubts:
First, they doubted that the Buddha, out of great compassion, would rise from nirvana and expound the wonderful Dharma again;
Second, they doubted that there would be another Buddha coming from another realm to dwell here and expound the Dharma;
Third, they doubted that Ananda would transform his body to become a Buddha and expound the Dharma for the assembly.
Therefore, the sutra begins with Thus have I heard to inspire faith and eliminate these three doubts.

The commentary on the Lotus Sutra says, Thus refers to the auspicious response. It is named in accordance with the capacity of the audience, and therefore it is established as a title without being wrong.
Sentient beings respond without being wrong, and the Tathagata responds in accordance with their capacities.
The transmitter of the sutra establishes Thus based on the teaching that emerges from the response.
The commentary on the Sutra of Immeasurable Meanings says, The sage expounds the Dharma only to reveal suchness.
Only suchness is correct, therefore it is called thus.
The Venerable Master said:
It is called thus because it is free from the five kinds of slander.
The first sentence, 'thus,' in this sutra is free from the slander of reification that adds something.
The second sentence, 'thus,' in this sutra is free from the slander of nihilism that subtracts something.
The third sentence, 'thus,' in this sutra is free from the contradictory slander of both existence and non-existence.
The fourth sentence, 'thus,' in this sutra is free from the foolish slander of neither existence nor non-existence.
The fifth sentence, 'thus,' in this sutra is free from the slander of idle speculation that is neither existent nor non-existent.
Guangzhai said:
Thus, before transmitting what was heard, the entire sutra is titled.
Thus, in this sutra, I personally heard from the Buddha.
It is simply to explain what I heard.
Emperor Wu of Liang said:
Thus, this meaning is spoken by the Buddha, so it is called thus.
The Tripiá¹­aka master with elongated ears said:
Thus, there are three kinds.
First, in terms of the Buddha, the buddhas of the three times speak without difference, which is called suchness. Because they speak the same, it is called thus.
Because of this, it can be trusted. Because of the same teaching.
Second, in terms of the Dharma, the true characteristics of all dharmas are the same in the past and present, so it is called suchness.
Because it is spoken according to suchness, it is called thus.
Since it speaks in accordance with principle, without increase or decrease, it is definitely trustworthy, so it is called thus.
Third, in terms of the Saá¹…gha, because Ä€nanda heard it and looked up to the Buddha's original teaching, what he transmitted is no different, so it is called suchness.
Forever free from faults, so it is called thus.
Moreover, thus means words of faith and obedience.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says: Thus have I heard generates faith.
Faithfully accepting and practicing generates wisdom.ğŸ”½Faith is the entrance, wisdom is the crossing over.
Faith is the initial foundation for entering the Dharma, wisdom is the profound method for ultimate attainment.
If one has faith, then the principles spoken of are in accord. If they are in accord, then the way of teacher and disciple is established.
Because of faith, the Dharma that is spoken can all be in accord with.
Because of accord, the two groups of speaker and listener establish teacher and disciple.
In this faith, there are roughly ten explanations:

First, as for faith, relying on sutras such as the Benevolent Kings Sutra, it is the initial cause for entering the holy ranks and the great step for realizing the truth. Therefore, the forty minds take faith as the foremost.
About to enter the holy ranks, there is the faculty of faith and the power of faith.
Because there is the faculty of faith, myriad wholesome qualities arise from this.
Because there is the power of faith, the four demons cannot subdue it. For this reason, the sutra begins by causing faith to arise.
Second, relying on the Abhidharma-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, faith is the excellent hand that partakes of the flavor of the Dharma.

Those who study the Buddha's teachings are like great dragons and elephants. Faith is the hand. Renunciation is the tusk. Mindfulness is the neck. Wisdom is the head. On their two shoulders they carry the wholesome qualities they have accumulated.
Because elephants use their trunks as hands when eating, those who study the Dharma first give rise to faith.
Third, learners are the great merchants' original plan for the Dharma treasure, so they first give rise to faith and obtain the noble wealth.
The *VyÄkhyÄ-Å›Ästra says, The seven noble treasures are faith, precepts, hearing, giving, wisdom, conscience, and shame.
Faith is one of them.
Fourth, the *YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra says, Entering all dharmas, desire is the root, because it gives rise to hope.
Attention is what produces it, because it repeatedly arouses it.

Feeling is what draws it in, because it is experienced in the mind.

Wisdom is what makes it supreme, because it distinguishes good and evil.

Since faith is the basis of desire, it is made to arise first.
Sixth, the Cheng Weishi Lun says: Faith is like a water-purifying pearl, able to clear turbid water, able to cure the naturally turbid nature of disbelief.
Therefore, Xuan Ni said:
Among the three - soldiers, food, and trust - trust cannot be abandoned.

The Chunqiu also says: If there is clear faith, even the hair of a marsh or the leaves of floating duckweed and water shield can be offered to ghosts and spirits, and can be presented to the crown prince.
Seventh, the Abhidharma-koÅ›a says: Pulling sentient beings out of the mud of birth and death, the true Dharma is the Buddha's hand, which is the main part.
Faith is the sentient beings' hand, which is the introduction.
With both hands joining, one emerges from the mud.
Eighth, various treatises say:
Faith can transcend evil paths and leave the causes of poverty and lowliness. Therefore, upon entering the sagehood, one has indestructible faith, so it is first required to arise.
The following three explanations are based on the sutra for interpretation.
Eighth, when crossing the great ocean, one relies on the hand to operate the boat;
when crossing the river of birth and death, one needs faith to give rise to wisdom.
Ninth, when seeing precious treasures, one uses the hand to pick them up;
when hearing the Dharma treasure, one relies on faith to obtain it.
Tenth, when traveling in the wilderness, one holds a sword in the hand to defend against the many bandits.
When giving rise to the source of birth and death, one has faith to give rise to the understanding of wisdom and cut off afflictions.
Therefore, at the beginning of the sÅ«tra, Thus have I heard, is for the sake of causing sentient beings to give rise to right faith.
The above combines to have twenty-six explanations.
As for I have heard, the bodhisattva who transmits the Dharma points to himself and says:
Such Dharma was personally heard from the Buddha.
Therefore, it is called I have heard.
I refers to the aggregates, the conventionally imputed person.
However, there are three kinds of I:
First, the falsely grasped I, which refers to the I that is wrongly conceived by non-Buddhists, etc.
Second, the provisional designation of self refers to the bliss, purity, permanence, and self of great nirvana, which is provisionally established to remove the inverted views of the two vehicles.
Third, the self of worldly usage refers to the names such as Devadatta that are commonly transmitted in the world.
Now, the transmitters of the Dharma follow the world and refer to themselves as I, which is different from the first two and is the great self of non-self.
Question:
The buddhas teach the Dharma in order to eliminate the grasping of self.
Why not say I hear the non-self, but rather say I hear?
Answer:
For four reasons, only I hear is used.
First, because it is easy to speak.
If it is said non-self, who is this said of?
Second, because it accords with the world.
Third, because it removes fear of non-self.
If it is said non-self, for whom is it practiced and studied?
Fourth, because there are such things as self, other, defilement, purity, cause, effect, and activities, therefore self is used.
Question:
If so, why not use a name, but only self?
Answer:
There are three meanings.
First, showing not contradicting worldly conventions.ğŸ”½Although the principle is to manifest the truth, the words do not contradict worldly conventions;
Although the principle is to manifest the wondrous, the words do not contradict the coarse.
This is to show that the truth is not apart from worldly conventions.
Second, I means the meaning of being the master and controller.

Ä€nanda is one who hears much and retains what he hears. His hearing accumulates, and he is fully equipped with the three kinds of wisdom and retains both the text and meaning. He has mastery over the teachings of the Tripiá¹­aka.
If he were addressed by his name, although it would accord with the correct principle, it would lack the meaning of having mastery over all dharmas.
Because of this, he is called I and not Ä€nanda.
Third, I means the meaning of intimacy.
The world commonly says:
I see and hear this, which is considered to be intimate and direct experience.
If it is said that Ä€nanda heard it, it may not be direct hearing, but received it from others.
Now, it is shown that he directly heard what the World-Honored One said, and it is not hearsay. In order to break others' webs of doubt, he does not address himself by name, but simply says I heard.
Hearing refers to the ear not producing consciousness but listening to and accepting what is spoken.
Now, abandoning the ear and taking the self as the general term, it is called I hear.

Although in the Mahayana, the combination of the sense organ, consciousness, mental factors, and object is called hearing, the sense organ is superior to consciousness, etc. in five ways, so the sense organ is called hearing.
If it is only hearing sound, it can only be in the ear, but since it takes names and meanings as objects, it is in the mind. Therefore, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says: Hearing refers to inference.
The ear is called hearing because it directly hears sounds and serves as a door for the mind, because the mind only hears through it.
What is accomplished through hearing is generally called hearing.
If it takes names and meanings as objects, it is called hearing.
Since it is in the mind, it is collectively called hearing. Abandoning the specific ear and mind, it is generally called I hear.
Taking the ear as the door, the imprints are stored in the general, and what is accomplished through hearing is generally called hearing, so it is called I hear.

Although at that time SubhÅ«ti also saw, perceived, and knew what the Buddha said, he wanted to realize the profound truth and first had to hear it, because in this world the Buddha's work is done through sound, and in order to realize enlightenment one must be perfumed by hearing. For these reasons, at the beginning of the sÅ«tra it does not say saw, perceived, and knew, but only I have heard.
In reality, at that time he also saw the Buddha's work being done through light and so forth in other buddha lands, and it could be said that he saw and so forth.
The Dragon Army and others say:
The Buddha only has three dharmas: great concentration, wisdom, and compassion. He has long been free from idle speculation and has never taught the Dharma.
Due to the power of the Buddha's compassionate original vow, the aspects of text and meaning arise in the consciousnesses of sentient beings.
Although these aspects of text and meaning arise based on the power of one's own wholesome roots, they are called the Buddha's teaching based on the dominant condition.
Because of the power of the ear faculty and one's own mental transformation, it is called I have heard.
Therefore AsvabhÄva says:
The essence of what is heard is the aggregation and manifestation of the direct and indirect teachings on the consciousness of the listener.
If that is so, how can the bodhisattvas be said to expound?
Because they are the dominant cause, it is said that they expound.
It is like the power of the gods and so forth causing one to obtain treatises, spells, and so forth in dreams.
Therefore, the sutra also says, From the time of attaining enlightenment until the time of nirvana, not a single word was spoken in between.
You also do not hear the words of Bandhuprabha and others saying, The Buddha, being free from discrimination, is called free from conceptual proliferation.
Isn't it that the Dharma that is expounded is called free from conceptual proliferation?
It means that by the power of the fundamental vows of those who are to hear, the characteristics of the text and meaning arise in the consciousness of the Tathagata.
These characteristics of the text and meaning, which arise from the wholesome roots of the Buddha's benefiting others, are called the Buddha's teaching.
Although the conscious mind of the listener does not directly attain them, they clearly manifest as if similar to those characteristics, and therefore it is called what I have heard.
Bandhuprabha said:
It is said that because the differences in consciousness of other continua cause the differences in consciousness of other continua to arise, they are each other's dominant conditions.
For this reason, the sutra says: The Dharma I have taught is like the leaves in my hand.
The Dharma I have not taught is like the leaves in the forest.
Here, the two explanations are given according to those two texts, interweaving them.
It should be known that the intention of saying this Thus have I heard is to avoid the faults of addition, subtraction, and error.

It means that this Dharma was heard by me from the Buddha, not from others, showing that the hearer has ability, and that all that is heard is free from the faults of addition, subtraction, and error.
It is not like the ignorant who lack ability, and all that they hear may not be free from the faults of addition, subtraction, and error.

When compiling the Dharma, those who transmit the Buddha's teachings rely on the TathÄgata's teachings. They first say these words to cause sentient beings to respectfully believe and accept them, saying, Such and such Dharma I have heard from the Buddha. The text and meaning are definitive, without any increase or decrease.
Therefore, those who hear it should listen correctly, contemplate it according to the principles, and diligently cultivate and study it.
Sutra: At one time.
Praise:
Second, the time when the teaching was spoken.
When the Dharma King begins to transform, those with the capacity gather. When the speaking and listening are finished, it is collectively called at one time.
This is based on the uninterrupted continuity of moments, the completion of speaking and listening, and the provisional name at one time.
There are two explanations in the treatise:
First, the time of principle.
The two groups of speakers and listeners are apart from the present only, and the activities of the five aggregates are born and extinguished in a moment.

The present Dharma has the meaning of repaying the past and leading to the future. The repaid is provisionally called the past, and the led is provisionally called the future, both provisionally established upon the present Dharma.

It is said that the five aggregates of dharmas of the listener are born and perish in an instant, with the preceding giving rise to the succeeding. The ultimate completion of the matter is provisionally established as the three times, collectively called at one time, not the one time of a single birth and cessation.
Second, the time of consciousness only.

The two groups of speakers and listeners transform the three time appearances on the conscious mind and give rise to them. They are actually present, but according to the mind's limited changes, they transform into short or long. The ultimate completion of the matter is collectively called at one time.
It is like seeing many lives in a dream. In the waking state, it is only the mind, and there are no real objects at all.

The listener's mind transformation of the three times is also like this. It is only the object of the mind, the non-associated compositional factor aggregate, the dharma realm, and the dharma element.

This word at one time is not definite about a single moment, not definite about a continuum, not definite about the four periods, six periods, eight periods, twelve periods, etc., and not definite about the years and time after attaining enlightenment, and is called at one time.

It is simply that when the faculties of the listeners are ripe and they inspire the Buddha to speak, and the speaker compassionately responds to the capacity of the listener, the speaking and listening are completed and are collectively called at one time.

It is not definite about a single moment because the assembly listening to the Dharma may have dull faculties. Even though the speaking may be short, the time for understanding may be long. Or the speaker may speak for a long time, and the listeners may also take a long time. They may still not understand in a single moment, so it is not a single moment.

It is also not definite about a continuum because the speaker may attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä« and explain the meaning of a single syllable, and everyone understands it. Or the listeners may attain pure ears and mind, and when they hear a single syllable, they are able to understand everything, so it is not a continuum.

Because in a single assembly, the faculties of the listeners are sharp or dull. The TathÄgata's spiritual power may either prolong a short thought to be long, or abbreviate many kalpas to be a short thought, which is also indefinite. Therefore, it is generally called at one time based on the completion of the teaching and listening, and cannot be specifically stated.

It is also indefinite in terms of the four seasons, six periods, eight periods, or twelve periods. The sun and moon illuminate the four continents in a day and a month. The length and shortness, noise and cold, near and far, day and night, and directions are indefinite, because the two continents always share the same activities.
Moreover, humans and other beings, as well as the gods above, do not have these four seasons or eight periods, etc.

The sÅ«tra is intended to circulate to the upper realms and directions. If the four seasons, etc. were mentioned, it would not spread everywhere, and therefore the four seasons, eight periods, etc. are not mentioned.

Also, it is not definitely based on the number of years after attaining enlightenment, because the Buddhas' bodies, whether of retribution or transformation, the length of their years, the near or far of their attainment of enlightenment, and the shallow or profound of the Dharma they expound, are each different, as seen by the ordinary beings and sages of the Three Vehicles.
Since the sÅ«tra is intended to be heard by the ordinary beings and sages of the Three Vehicles together, it does not specifically state the number of years after attaining enlightenment.
However, among the various sÅ«tras, some speak of four periods. The Nirvana Sutra says on the fifteenth day of the second month.

Some speak of six periods, eight periods, twelve periods, etc. The Nirvana Sutra says at dawn, when chewing willow twigs, and the Diamond PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says after the meal, putting away the robes and alms bowl,
washing the feet, arranging the seat, and sitting down, which is spoken at noon.ğŸ”½The Sutra on Rebirth in the Pure Land says in the first part of the night.
The Sutra on the Instructons in the Last Journey says in the middle of the night, silent and still.

Some say that after attaining enlightenment, the number of years and the time period are as follows. The DaÅ›abhÅ«mika-sÅ«tra says, On the second seventh day, he spoke in the Maá¹‡i Jewel Treasury Hall in the palace of the Heaven of Freely Partaking of Others' Emanations.
The Lotus Sutra says, For three seven-day periods he contemplated this, then went to VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« and turned the wheel of the four truths.
The Sutra of Immeasurable Meanings also says, More than forty years have passed since I attained enlightenment.

Although there are these statements, they are made according to the places and cities where the teachings were heard and compiled. They are not the initial title or time of teaching. Therefore, one should simply say 'at one time.'
Question:
In terms of place, there is purity and impurity, and the place is definitely described according to the capacities of the audience.
In terms of time, there is a difference between ordinary beings and sages. How can it be acceptable not to distinguish them?
Answer:
Describing the place as pure or impure, purity and impurity can be definitely known.
Describing the time as short or long, ordinary and sage cannot be used as a standard.
The assembly of beings has sharp and dull faculties. How can the length of time be determined?
Therefore, the place can be determined and described, but the time is only generally mentioned.
Sutra: At one time, the Blessed One.
Commentary:
This explains the teacher.
The Buddha has ten epithets, this is the tenth.
BhagavÄn is a sound, Brahman means possessing virtue.
If one possesses this BhagavÄn sound, one can break the four demons and possess the six kinds of virtues, and is called the Blessed One.
First, the four demons of the segmented birth and death are: 1. the demon of afflictions, 2. the demon of aggregates, 3. the demon of death, and 4. the demon of the heavenly beings.
The one hundred and twenty-eight fundamental afflictions and secondary afflictions are called the demon of afflictions.
The five contaminated aggregates are called the demon of aggregates.
Impermanent death and cessation are called the demon of death.
The son of the heavenly king of the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin Heaven is called the demon of the heavenly beings.
These four are able to destroy good things and cause sentient beings to revolve in birth and death, with deep and heavy harm, and are biased as being called demons.
The Buddha is able to destroy them, and is called the Blessed One.
If according to the transformed appearance, under the bodhi tree he entered the vajra-like samÄdhi and destroyed the demon of afflictions.
He abandoned one-fifth of his lifespan, and in the twin sala trees he entered nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, destroying the demon of the aggregates.
He remained for three months after death, in order to destroy the demon of death, because he was able to remain in the body due to his mastery over death.
Under the bodhi tree, after attaining enlightenment, he first entered the samÄdhi of loving-kindness in order to destroy the demon of the heavens. According to the truth, he destroyed it.

Bodhisattvas in the tenth stage manifest the eight phases of practice and attainment, and are able to subdue the demon of the heavens. Although in the praise of the virtues of bodhisattvas below in this sÅ«tra, bodhisattvas from the eighth stage and above subdue demons and adversaries and control non-Buddhists, praising their ability,
it is not that they are just now destroying them.
Moreover, being able to destroy the four is only for those above the eighth ground, so now praising them is not speaking of the heavenly demons being destroyed only from the eighth ground.

As for the aggregate demon, before the seventh ground there is the coarse contaminated aggregate of the death of the transformation body, which may not yet be extinguished or may be abandoned in the first ground. Above the eighth ground, the coarse aggregate demon of the birth of the transformation body is definitely abandoned.
If the subtle one is abandoned, it is necessary to attain liberation. After becoming a buddha, the four knowledges are completely perfected, and the contaminated one is then abandoned.

As for the afflictive demon, the afflictions that are companions of the uncommon ignorance are called abandoned by subduing in the fourth ground of the Joyous of the ten abodes. In the stage of added effort, they are able to be suddenly subdued and abandoned.
The seeds of the discriminating afflictions that are latent are eliminated and abandoned in the first ground.
The innate afflictions are gradually subdued and abandoned before the first ground. Above the first ground, they are able to be suddenly subdued and abandoned.
However, there are bodhisattvas who sometimes give rise to them before the seventh ground, but above the eighth ground they definitely subdue and abandon them.
When the adamantine mind arises, the seeds and habitual tendencies are both exhausted, and one forever abandons them.
As for the cognitive hindrances, the discriminating ones are like the discriminating afflictions and mÄras.
The innate ones are eliminated on each of the ten stages.
Those in the six consciousnesses are abandoned simultaneously with the seventh consciousness at the adamantine mind.
As for the mÄra of death, the mÄra of death of the stage of transformation and change is forever abandoned upon entering the first stage and receiving a transformed body.
Some do not receive a transformed body until the eighth stage, and then they abandon it.
The death of the stage of transformation and change is definitely broken through on the path of liberation when one becomes a buddha.
Now it is shown that the World Honored One has broken through all four, and is therefore called BhagavÄn.
Therefore the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says: Sitting in peace and ease on the wondrous seat of enlightenment, he is able to break through the four mÄras and is therefore called BhagavÄn.
He also possesses six virtues.

As for the six virtues, the MahÄyÄna-abhidharma-samuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ says: Self-mastery, splendor, and dignity, fame, auspiciousness, and nobility - one should know that these six meanings in general are called bhagavat.
First, the meaning of self-mastery, because one is never bound to the afflictions.
Second, the meaning of splendor, because one is refined by the blazing fire of wisdom.
Third, the meaning of dignity, because one is adorned with various excellent characteristics.
Fourth, the meaning of fame, because one is universally known for perfecting all excellent virtues.
Fifth, the meaning of auspiciousness, because one is revered and worshipped by all worlds and praised by all.
Sixth, the meaning of nobility, because one always employs skillful means to benefit and bring peace to all sentient beings without slacking off, possessing all virtues.
Because of these six virtues, one is called bhagavat.
Only this one name comprehensively includes many virtues, and the world all respects it.
Therefore, all non-Buddhists all call their original teachers bhagavat.
For this reason, the World-Honored One has all the scriptures begin with this name.
In the past, all the translators wanted to abbreviate it, regardless of whether the meaning was complete or not, and placed the Buddha's name.
Among the ten epithets, Buddha is the ninth, and BhagavÄn is the tenth. The eleventh name comprehensively includes the nine virtues, so it is chanted first now.
But some have changed it and placed the title of Buddha. Although the meaning expressed is no different, the name and meaning of the expression are slightly different.
For this reason, the Dharma Master Bodhiruci of the Later Wei Dynasty said:
Although the word BhagavÄn is slightly distorted, the meaning is no different.
As explained in detail in the Buddha Ground Treatise.
Question:

Answer:
According to the place where the transformation is given, it is the transformation body.
The Bodhisattva in the middle said again:

Therefore, it is known that it is the other enjoyment Buddha in general.
The transformed body is not real and is not the one who expounds the Dharma, but the merit is attributed to the fundamental Dharma body.
The body that responds to beings cannot arise alone, it must be born through transformation, and is common to the enjoyment of self and others.
But because the capacities of beings are not the same, one place is seen differently, and it cannot be definitively said that the essence of the transformation or reward body is present.
Judging from the location, it is definitely the transformation Buddha.
Therefore, the sutra below says, Shakyamuni Tathagata conceals immeasurable noble merits, in order to save these inferior people, therefore he manifests this defiled land.
Therefore, it is known to be the transformation body.
Now, in order to show that the honored master's Dharma must be superior, the first part of the sutra places Bhagavat.
Sutra: Residing in the city of Vaisali, in the grove of Amrapali.
Commentary:
This is the place of transformation.
This is the territory of central India, the country is called Vaisali, which means widely adorned, the old translations have Vyaghrabodhi, Vaisali, and Vyaghrabodhi, all of which are erroneous.

The country is over 5,000 li in circumference, and although the capital city is now in ruins, its foundations still remain, 60 to 70 li in circumference. The royal palace foundations are 4 to 5 li in circumference.
Five or six li northwest of the palace, there is a monastery following the SammitÄ«ya school.
Beside it is a stupa where the Buddha expounded the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra, and where the elder's son RatnÄkara offered a canopy.
Three or four li north of the monastery is the AmrapÄlÄ« Grove, which she offered to the Buddha, and where the Buddha often stayed.
Three or four li northeast of the monastery is the former residence of VimalakÄ«rti.
Not far from here is a shrine, shaped like a pile of stones.
It is said:
It is the place where VimalakÄ«rti expounded the Dharma while sick, piling up stones.

The capital city has no other name, it is named after the country, and the city is also named after the capital. Therefore, the country is called Vast and Majestic, and the city is also called Vast and Majestic.

Vast and Majestic means vast and great, surpassing the capitals of other countries.
Majestic means beautifully adorned, surpassing the palaces of all kings.

First, the bad friend who is like a relative, whom one fears and submits to, but who actually has no friendly intentions.
Second, the bad friend who speaks nicely, whose words accord with one's wishes but whose actions go against them.
Third, respecting and following evil friends, although one respects and follows them, one does not have a mind to admonish them regarding their good and evil deeds.
Fourth, evil friends are companions in doing evil, such as drinking alcohol together, gambling, indulging in sex and singing and dancing, etc.
Among these four kinds of friends, each has four types that should be kept away.
There are four kinds of good friends:
First, friends who stop wrongdoing, because they stop each other from doing evil things.
Second, friends who have compassion, because they sympathize with each other in times of suffering.
Third, friends who benefit others, because they share good things with each other.
Fourth, friends who do the same wholesome deeds, because they do the same wholesome things together.
Each of these has four types, and all should be closely associated with.
These bodhisattvas are these four kinds of good friends for sentient beings.

Sutra: Forever free from all hindrances, coverings, and entanglements.
Praise:
This reveals the merit of the bodhisattva's freedom from defilements.
Hindrances refer to obstructions, of which there are two kinds:
First, the afflictive hindrances; second, the hindrances to that which is to be known.
The afflictive hindrances take as their essence the one hundred twenty-eight fundamental afflictions and secondary afflictions that are eliminated by seeing and cultivation in the three realms.
The hindrances to that which is to be known take as their essence the greed, delusion, pride, etc. that are eliminated by seeing and cultivation in the three realms and that all obstruct cognition.
As for the number of these [hindrances], they are gradually and suddenly subdued and eliminated, all as explained in the treatises.

These bodhisattvas, at the eighth stage, have already subdued or eliminated the active forms of the two hindrances in the first six consciousnesses, and have already eliminated their seeds, and therefore it is said that they seek to be free from them.
The five hindrances are so called because they cover and obscure the mind of the practitioner, preventing it from being pure.
There are five kinds:
1. The hindrance of sensual desire, 2. the hindrance of anger, 3. the hindrance of drowsiness and sleep, 4. the hindrance of restlessness and remorse, and 5. the hindrance of doubt.
These five are hindrances at three times.
Sensual desire is a hindrance to leaving the home life. Once one has left the home life, one may commit sexual misconduct and have a sense of awakening.
Anger is a hindrance that, when one does not have a sense of awakening, gives rise to further anger.
If one does not commit sexual misconduct and studies concentration and wisdom, the last three become hindrances:ğŸ”½When first studying to still the mind, drowsiness and sleep are a hindrance;
Next, when studying to uplift the mind, restlessness and remorse are a hindrance;
If one abides in the state of equanimity, doubt can become an obstruction.
These five are obstructed.
Therefore, they are established as hindrances.
The entanglements are called entanglements because they repeatedly arise and entangle the mind of the practitioner, thus they are established as entanglements.
There are eight kinds, namely shamelessness, lack of conscience, torpor, sleep, restlessness, worry, jealousy, and stinginess.
The first two obstruct precepts, the next two obstruct concentration, the next two obstruct wisdom, and the last two obstruct benefiting oneself and others.
For those who have left the household life, stinginess and jealousy frequently arise in the door of benefiting oneself and others.
The two hindrances already include all defilements, and among them, the predominant ones are specifically mentioned as hindrances and entanglements.
The three leaks, four clingings, bodily fetters, bonds, and so forth are all understood to be already eliminated.
The old translation says all already pure, the meaning of the text is difficult to understand, it means the two hindrances are exhausted.

Sutra: Attained all dharanis and eloquence.
Commentary:
This explains the merit of perfecting the six kinds of eloquence.
First, uninterrupted eloquence, because it is a continuous flow without interruption.
Second, superior eloquence, because it cannot be subdued.
Third, mindful eloquence, because it recollects the teachings.
Fourth, wise eloquence, because it analyzes all dharmas.
Fifth, concentrated eloquence, because it skillfully explains all samadhis.

Since it is neither the four unobstructed understandings nor the seven kinds of eloquence, it is separately perfected as six.
The single character eloquence is used throughout the middle.
This sixth eloquence is included in the Dharma and meaning of the four unobstructed understandings;
The first five kinds of eloquence are all included in the understanding.
This first one is included in the fourth uninterrupted eloquence of the seven kinds of eloquence.
This second is included in the seventh of the seven, because it is the most supreme and wonderful in all worlds.
This fourth is the fifth of those, because it is without error. Mindfulness and concentration are both penetrating.
According to their respective applications, the subsequent wisdom is their essence.
